dt: {bc}a distinct often numbered section of a writing
{bc}a stipulation in a document (such as a contract or a creed)
{bc}a nonfictional prose composition usually forming an independent part of a publication (such as a magazine)
{bc}a document setting forth the terms of an agreement

dt.t: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has approved the certificate of filing of the {wi}articles{/wi} of merger and plan of merger …

dt: {bc}any of a small set of words or affixes (such as {it}a, an{/it}, and {it}the{/it}) used with nouns to limit or give definiteness to the application
{bc}a member of a class of things
{bc}a thing or person of a particular and distinctive kind or class

et: Middle English, "item or statement (in a set of rules, doctrines, etc.), clause in a statute or will, item or detail of concern," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}articulus{/it} "connecting point of two bones, joint, part of a limb or digit between two joints, point of time, clause of a document, pronoun or pronominal adjective," from {it}artus{/it} (genitive {it}artūs{/it}) "joint, limb, part of the body" + {it}-culus,{/it} diminutive suffix; Latin {it}artus{/it} going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}r̥-tú-{/it} "joining" (zero-grade derivative of the verbal base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}er-{/it} "fit, join"), whence also Greek {it}artýs{/it} "order, arrangement" (recorded only by the grammarian Hesychius; from which Greek {it}artýein{/it} "to arrange, prepare"), Armenian {it}ard{/it} (genitive {it}ardu{/it}) "order," Sanskrit {it}ṛtúḥ{/it} "fixed time, order, rule," Avestan {it}ratu-{/it} "period of time" {ma}{mat|arm:3|}{/ma}

As a grammatical term Latin {it}articulus{/it} was a translation of Greek {it}árthron{/it} "connecting point, joint," which in the Stoic grammatical tradition designated both the pronoun ({it}árthron hōrísmenon{/it} "definite article") and the article ({it}árthron aóriston/aorístōdes{/it} "indefinite article," though Greek possessed only what is now considered a definite article in traditional grammar). In the later work of the grammarian Apollonius Dyscolus (2nd century {sc}a.d.{/sc}) the pronoun was given a distinct term ({it}antōnymía{/it}). The Roman grammarian {et_link|quintilian|Quintilian:b} clearly understood {it}articulus{/it} to mean "article" in the current sense in stating that "our speech [i.e., Latin, in contrast with Greek] has no need of articles" ("noster sermo articulos non desiderat").
shortdef: a distinct often numbered section of a writing
a stipulation in a document (such as a contract or a creed)

dt.t: He went to Durham Grammar School, was {wi}articled{/wi} to a solicitor in Newcastle at seventeen, moved to another firm in London at twenty …

shortdef: to bind by articles (as of apprenticeship)
